text:
Nepal continues to be popular tourism destination despite earthquake Published on : Friday, August 21, 2015
Nepal is still considered a popular tourism destination, receiving visitors from all over the world, despite a massive earthquake that rocked the country last April.
Nepal Tourism Board (NTB) administrative chief, Ramesh Kumar Adhikari said although bringing in more tourists to Nepal had become an uphill climb after the disaster, they believed they could still lure more tourists, including from Malaysia.
“Some people are still afraid to come because of the earthquake that hit Nepal in April, but we still receive visitors from all over the world.
“We are famous for our nature, culture and adventure tourism,” he said at a press conference on business partnership between the Malaysian Association of Tour and Travel Agents (MATTA) outbound members and Nepal inbound agents, in Kuala Lumpur, Thursday.
Nepal’s High Commissioner to Malaysia, Dr Niranjan Man Singh Bansyat said he did not see the drop in value of the Malaysian currency as a factor for Malaysians not to visit Nepal.
“It is cheaper to visit Nepal since RM1 now equals to RP26. Our hotels are also promoting 50 percent discounts and the hotel operators may also extend the promotion period if the demand is positive.
“Therefore, I invite all Malaysians to visit Nepal as everywhere is safe and opened to be visited,” he added.
Nepal was hit by a massive earthquake measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale on April 25, killing 9,012 people including foreign tourists.
Meanwhile, MATTA deputy president Rohizam Md Yusof said it would help to educate the local travel agents and operators to explore more tourism markets in Nepal. He said it was important for travel agents to understand the tourism products so as to suit Malaysians’ preferences.
Rohizam said there were many tourism products that could be explored by the Malaysian industry players to be promoted to their clients, such as suitable places for families, couples to go for honeymoon, religious products, natural places and extreme sports.
